Angular Lifecycle OnChanges Hook.description: Lifecycle hook: Called before any other lifecycle hook
body: //Called before any other lifecycle hook. Use it to inject dependencies, but avoid any serious work here.

Angular Lifecycle OnInit Hook.description: Lifecycle hook: Called after the constructor
body: //Called after the constructor, initializing input properties, and the first call to ngOnChanges.

Angular Lifecycle DoCheck Hook.description: Lifecycle hook: Called every time that the input properties of a component or a directive are checked
body: //Called every time that the input properties of a component or a directive are checked. Use it to extend change detection by performing a custom check.

Angular Lifecycle AfterContentInit Hook.description: Lifecycle hook: Called after ngOnInit when the component's or directive's content has been initialized
body: //Called after ngOnInit when the component's or directive's content has been initialized.

Angular Lifecycle AfterContentChecked Ho.description: Lifecycle hook: Called after every check of the component's or directive's content
body: //Called after every check of the component's or directive's content.

Angular Lifecycle AfterViewInit Hook.description: Lifecycle hook: Called after ngAfterContentInit when the component's view has been initialized
body: //Called after ngAfterContentInit when the component's view has been initialized. Applies to components only.

Angular Lifecycle AfterViewChecked Hook.description: Lifecycle hook: Called after every check of the component's view. Applies to components only
body: //Called after every check of the component's view. Applies to components only.

Angular Lifecycle OnDestroy Hook.description: Lifecycle hook: Called before the instance is destroyed
body: //Called once, before the instance is destroyed.

* Since every action label passes through this function it
* is a good place to ensure all of our action labels
throw new Error(`Action type "${label}" is not unique"`);
export function reducer(state = initialState, action: ${class}.Actions ): State {
* For each action type in an action group, make a simple
* enum object for all of this group's action types.
* The 'type' utility function coerces strings into string
* literal types and runs a simple check to guarantee all
* action types in the application are unique.
* Every action is comprised of at least a type and an optional
* payload. Expressing actions as classes enables powerful
* Export a type alias of all actions in this action group
* so that reducers can easily compose action types

Angular 1 OrderBy.description: For performance reasons, no comparable pipe exists in Angular 2. Instead, use component code to order or sort results. If you need the same ordering or sorting code in several templates, consider building a custom pipe.

Angular 1 Filter.description: For performance reasons, no comparable pipe exists in Angular 2. Do all your filtering in the component. If you need the same filtering code in several templates, consider building a custom pipe.
